title: At close of business on 18 March 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 29 January 2020?
preds:
Fed just shot all of their ammunition.like the FED said we will use our power at the 11nth hour to produce effects in 3d and 4th quarter.
I am betting this is like the 9/11 attack and aviation,retail, hotel, restaurants will lose Quarter 2
but GDP will move to positive by elecction day.
The velocity of money in consumer spending for wide swaths of consumer demand at 70% GDP
People are now afraid to spend like the shock of 9-11
Its 1919 without Versaille, ww1 and the destruction of france and germany and substitute chinese for Spanish flu.
1919 was a terrible reesssion. Starvation occurred throughout the worldd.hoover made his name in refugee relief and single handedly saved Belgium, war torn France and Germany and Poland from absolute starvation. Thats why we have the Hoover Institute for War and Peace at Stanford. 
  Madame SecretaryCondi Rice formr Provost Stanford U 1975-1979 2 woman as Sec. State runs.
I would be more confident today if Stanford and Penn who will have the vaccine in 6 months and our state governors and mayors ran the U.S. government. From the date of his accession to what will be viewed as the last Imperial Presidency, Donald Trump was given a put "The Trump Put" by a market irrational and exuberant with de-regulation and fossil fuels.
This market rout like the end of the Greenspan put will not be reversed overnight.  When the US people vote  in November all those gains in  market assets..... back to where they started on trump's election.
in retrospect these paper profits on stock appreciation and asset values 2017-2020 illusory.
As Ibbotsen states pe ratio is between 10 and 15 for last 150 years.
Fossil fuels in the form of oil reserves will never be worth as much again.
From Exxon and Shell to the wildcat fracking fields of North Dakota, Texas,and the Marcellus back in PA the party is over permanently. I will not be buying  Aramco ipo. Russia is on its knees and Putin will be on shaky ground at 40 a barrel. Gone in 2 years
like Ayatollah.
I'd be concerned if I was  an erstwhile ally like Iran, KSA every opec country is now an enemy of putin for survival.   this could be the end of the fossil fuel era. Those stocks not coming back for 2 years
Rate has been lowered as emergency cut.   It’s never then be raised up again inter meeting in this time frame.

My assumption is that talk is a lot cheaper than action in this case, but stranger things have happened.
Cut now and future actions get harder and harder to achieve. My money is in April and June if warranted.
I don't think the situation forecast by @Chrisp will materialize this week. The blood in the streets seems to be drying up at the moment.
Pressure on Fed in light of coronavirus

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-forex/swingeing-fed-rate-cut-bets-send-dollar-reeling-to-one-month-low-idUSKBN20P02T?il=0
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-centralbanks-cuts/u-s-bank-lobby-economist-predicts-global-rate-cut-coming-this-wednesday-idUSKBN20O2CY
Looks like it will happen quite soon.

The pressure increases for a rate cut.  The risk is (1) a rate cut does not matter when the problem is on the supply side as in China contracting output and (2) they and no one else really knows when the coronavirus will peak and things return to normal.
The idea of a cut seems to have gone mainstream and is now widely expected so I'm weighting this aggressively.

Futures had a 29% chance of a fed cut on Wed.  Haven't looked more recently but with the continued route in the the Dow, tha  number can only be higher.  Statistically, the March meeting is the most likely to have a change.  The reason isn't hard to discern.  March April is when the US govt has the highest tax receipts on the lowest borrowings so the impact on interest rates to the US govt is lower.  This logic works for increases, not so much for decreases.    But.... As I speak (Sunday night), futures are pointing to another 500 point loss Monday Morning.  This will require more action to combat fear:   A speech by the President.  One from the Fed chairman, One from the CDC and the Surgeon general.  Strategy:  Right now the crowd is at 20%.  I don't think the crowd has moved fast enough on this.   I think the odds are at least 60%, maybe 70%.  People are losing trillions in the stock market - this demands response. Way to play:  If panic and fear backs off, moderate in the next 3-7 days, moderate this bet to zero lower.   But I think panic is going to set in.

Adjusting down only slightly. The Fed does no have enough data to act yet and the statement said they are monitoring the situation closely. The markets are pricing in a big cut, but we don't know which way this is going to fall and the Fed could end up only running out of ammo before the real impact is known

Shifting my forecast to include a possibility of a rate cut this month. Some in trade press say a 1/4 point cut is already baked into the numbers by traders. Pressure may mount on the Fed to act before the data is talking.
Hattip @neuromancer for suggesting I look again.

Hattip @neuromancer once again for an excellent analysis, his words are better than my thoughts. :-)
The Fed will talk and get mileage just from the talk. Action may come later if actually warranted. 
April / June more likely once data available, today it's just fear.

Moderating this position because covid may not be a demand dominated shock, and it could increase inflation in some ways due to supplies of products running short. Explanation here: https://twitter.com/paulkrugman/status/1233486467860705282

Powell Opens Door to Rate Cut on ‘Evolving’ Risks From Virus [1] in the March meeting due to the fear of potential covid-19 outbreaks in the US.   [1]  https://finance.yahoo.com/news/powell-says-fed-poised-act-193253922.html

China manufacturing and non-manufacturing PMI at all time lows for February show possible economic consequences of virus epidemic in US, so hard not to factor that into the Fed's thinking. Market pricing in 3 cuts by December. Fed not following along quite yet. Clarida said on Tuesday it is  "too soon to speculate" on effects or if there will be a "material effect", then in the midst of the sell off on Friday, Powell said they are that the virus poses evolving risks, Fed is monitoring closing, will use all the tools and act as appropriate. All this being said, seem like they need to see actual data to cut, not fears or speculation of declining data. Are lower prices for financial assets enough data? Maybe. Increasing prob of a cut to 25%, "monitoring closely" this week.
Updating for coronavirus - while rate cut might not be the "appropriate" policy response, fixed income markets imply a rate cut so raising probability

In a somewhat rational world, the Fed would keep rates the same in March. The economic data at this point don't warrant either a raise or a cut.  Most of the economic indicators have been doing just fine. Furthermore, Fed officials have been making a point of saying that there's no need to cut rates, and that it's too soon to tell if the Cornoavirus will cause a change of policy.  They have, for the most part, been really adamant about staying the course. In a purely economic sense, the Coronavirus is having a supply-side impact, and monetary policy is a demand-side solution. So in a certain sense, a rate cut at this point would not be that helpful. And yet...and yet...it just doesn't always work that way. The markets are tanking.  The markets are tanking and there could be a spillover from Wall Street to Main Street as investors head for bonds and liquidity dries up.  The markets are tanking and there is a lot of pressure on the Fed to do something.   At the one end there are calls for an emergency meeting to cut rates. At the other end, Tim Duy says that Chairman Powell should at least acknowledge that the Fed might cut rates at some point.  And then there is the Rate Cutter-in-Chief, who has never let up on his screams for rate cuts. I think the Fed is between a rock and a hard place here.  If they cut rates soon, it will almost certainly be seen as capitulating to markets (as opposed to their mission).  This narrative played out once before between late-2018 and mid--2019, and it's not one that Fed officials like.  On the other hand, if they remain adamantly hawkish, they risk being seen as blind and deaf to the unfolding crisis and potential economic impacts. I'm going to stick with a 99% unchanged rate forecast for 18 March. I'm basically in an "in for a dime, in for a dollar" mode, and I don't think changing my forecast to reflect the amount of uncertainty surrounding the question would really make any difference.  To the extent that I think there's something meaningful to say in the way of justification, I think a material pivot this soon after such staunch statements of staying the course might be perceived as being wishy-washy and beholden to Wall Street.  But I do think the verbiage out of Fed mouths is going to start sounding a lot more dovish and amenable to cuts later in the year.
It's likely reckless not to cut rates as the picture becomes clear that covid isn't going away.
Reaffirming forecast. If anything the odds of a cut would be higher.
Fed signaled no hikes for the near term.
The current approach by the Fed seems appropriate to support sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labour market conditions, and inflation returning to the 2 percent target.
Hard to see conditions changing enough to justify an unexpected rate increase.

Softening of sectors such as petroleum due to global demand weakening. Covid hurting supply chains and keeping products off market. Fed might do a small cut to boost confidence and anticipate the effects that lag behind economic shocks such as these.
Historically Fed does not cut rate during an election year.
factoring in some risk from coronavirus, but more likely than not things will stay the same.

I am holding steady at 99% probability the rate will remain the same on 18 March.   Although industrial production decreased a bit in January, retail sales were at the consensus level.  Employment/jobless numbers have been good, and consumer sentiment is high.  No core signals calling for a rate cut.  At the same time, CPI was a bit above the Fed's target, but not enough to raise any eyebrows (or rates).  Also, a number of Fed officials have spoken recently, and with one exception seem committed to current rates for the time being.  They are leaving the door open just a crack for a rate cut due to any Cononavirus economic implications, but I don't think it will explode enough in four or five weeks to warrant a course change.

It’s an election year. The Republican Party will work with the Federal Reserve and banks to make the economy look good and that means people need money to spend, money must be available to borrow and lower rates help lower bank costs. If borrowing rates are high, the banks want to mitigate their risk and raise requirements for lending. I believe that type of thinking will lower rates through November.
It was 1.75 in January and still 1.75 on Feb 13. It is projected to remain the same by most models.
The Fed will wait longer to react to China’s epidemic. Otherwise, they will think the economy is OK.
I’m betting on a much higher chance of a rate cut than the people I follow. I think Wuhan will have an impact.

There is nothing analytic behind this, but in watching the CME's FedWatch trends, and reading blogs written by Fed watchers, I think a move towards higher rates in the next five weeks is extremely unlikely, and a move towards lower rates is only a tiny bit more likely.  Members of the Fed have said over and over again that they see stability, and even though Jerome Powell's post-meeting remarks seemed to crack the door a bit for a rate change at some point down the road, I think it's unlikely to happen this soon. Edit: The ADP numbers this morning make it even more difficult to believe a rate cut is coming in March.
Economy still stable. Barring significant earnings surprises, likely to remain.

Why would the Fed raise rates?  Because the economy is heating too quickly.  This does not seem to be the case as (a) GDP growth is positive but moderate, and (b) inflation is holding steady despite great employment figures.  Furthermore, after the pounding the Fed took last year from Trump when they raised rates, and with Trump recently saying at Davos that he could get used to negative rates, it's just hard to imagine the Fed raising them except under the most dire of circumstances.  Why would the Fed lower rates?  Because economic growth is slowing significantly.  This does not seem to be at all the case.  The 800 pound gorilla of the GDP is consumer spending, and -- as Tim Duy pointed out in his most recent "Fed Watch" blog post -- consumer spending is anything but weak.    Both trains of thought have been supported over the past several weeks when 10 Fed governors and regional Presidents indicated that they expect rates to remain where they are for the foreseeable future.
Thanks to the magic of hedonic adjustments, CPI remains at a nice level. Economy still doing fine. They'll take the path of least resistance.
I don't think it's going to move by March.
Continued need for growth by the Republican party.
Feds won't want to upset the stock market or Trump
I think it will be higher but the fed will think it should stay the same regardless of inflation
Political pressure will keep it the same or lower.
No reason to expect change, economy is fairly stable

A raft of strong economic data, (too?) low inflation. I think the risk of tightening is incrementally higher but still very low. on the downside there is mostly the small risk of a significant macroeconomic shock. Passage of time. The net result is that I'm leaving my estimates as-is.

Thanks to @sreichau for the reference.  Looks like everybody is happy to keep it unchanged. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-barkin/fed-policymakers-broadly-see-eye-to-eye-on-2020-outlook-idUSKBN1Z21N4

At close of business on 18 March 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 29 January 2020?
We will be coasting until November. Luckily for US the decade of slow growth has left us in a good spot.

A strong ADP report yesterday points firmly towards not lowering the rate.  There are not strong enough signs of inflation to think rates might be raised, although I think this is slightly more likely than lowering

FED will be continuing QE program through Q1 with inflation well within "hold" zone. CPI is running over 2%, while core PCE is just under. Would take a large market sell-off for FED to cut as economic data will not deteriorate this quickly.
Adjusted slightly (by eyeball) after updating my end-January estimate. This estimate needs to be updated at the end of January or at any other rate change.
I've used an event tree building on my simple analysis for the January question.

2 Fed meetings in this period, statements and situation point to no change. What will change my mind is 29 Jan's fed meeting if they change their tone (they seem to have maintained through all the trade war rhetoric) or if the Iran-US situation picks up.
First forecast on this one. I am mainly just mildly extremizing the principal CME Fed Watch forecast until I see more data.
Forecast unchanged, just adding this interesting article for reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-barkin/fed-policymakers-broadly-see-eye-to-eye-on-2020-outlook-idUSKBN1Z21N4
I do not see any scenarios in this given time frame in which they change the rate, they may say they're looking at the date but no decision will be made by this date

it's 3 month later, as I expect the trade war with China is getting into phase 2, market may price in more uncertainty, after the optimistic mood settle down a little bit.  China is still battling with its economic issue.  as a world economy barometer, fed rate is more likely to stay put.
FED signals no change in last meeting, Futures market over 80%
